Award.AwardTitle: NRI-Small: Core Technologies for MRI-powered Robots

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this project is to create a transformative robotic technology that utilizes Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) systems to power, control and image robots under the guidance and control of a clinician. Specifically, the research effort will be organized around three tasks: (1) creation of design principles for MRI-powered actuators, (2) development of motion planning and control algorithms for MRI-powered robots, and (3) design of MRI pulse sequences for closed-loop motor control. This tether-less robot technology addresses the needs for small, low cost medical robots identified in the Roadmap for US Robotics and can be exploited for robots ranging in size from centimeters down to fractions of a millimeter. At the centimeter scale, it could be used for robots designed to crawl inside body cavities to perform interventions and also for robotic prosthetic implants. At the millimeter and sub-millimeter scale, groups of MRI-powered robots can swim inside fluid-filled regions of the body to perform targeted therapies, such as drug and cell delivery, or to assemble as a sensor network. Two testbeds at these different scales will be used to evaluate and demonstrate the technology.

This research addresses a largely unexplored frontier in medical robotics that could revolutionize the standard of care for many serious medical conditions currently associated with both high mortality rates and high societal costs. The location of the PI's lab inside a teaching hospital provides a unique environment to integrate the research and education of the engineering and medical disciplines. To promote an understanding of engineering and medicine along with the value of learning and research to low income and minority school students, the project team will partner with local educational organizations. Furthermore, the project technology will consist of algorithms and software that can be utilized by researchers and educators throughout the country to provide fundamentally new capabilities to existing multi-million dollar equipment. The ultra-minimally invasive medical robots developed using this technology can potentially provide substantial societal benefits in terms of reduced trauma, precise image-based control and lower cost.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project created a robotic technology that utilizes Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) systems to power, control and image robots under the guidance and control of a clinician. This tetherless robot technology has broad applications in medicine and biology and addresses the needs for small, low cost medical robots identified in the Roadmap for US Robotics. A unique advantage of this technology is that it can be exploited for medical robots ranging in length scale from tens of centimeters down to fractions of a millimeter. At the large end of the scale, hand-sized robots can be placed on the patient and used to steer needles to targets inside the body for drug delivery or to acquire biopsies. At the millimeter and micron scale, groups of MRI-powered robots can swim inside fluid-filled regions of the body, e.g., the spinal canal, to perform targeted therapies, such as drug and cell delivery, or to assemble as a sensor network.

The fundamental challenge of this project is that MR scanners are not designed to control robots and, furthermore, the metallic parts needed to generate robot motion can interfere with MR imaging. Outcomes of the project include: (1) the development of real-time robot control software on a clinical scanner that can be easily adapted to new applications; (2) demonstration of an MRI-powered linear actuator that can produce over 9N force (sufficient to puncture the human prostate capsule) while not interfering with tissue imaging; (3) creation of control strategies for robots with many degrees of freedom, e.g., a robot that can orient a needle as well as advance it to a tissue target; (4) development of techniques enabling millimeter-scale swimming robots to generate large forces, e.g., to penetrate tissue or to release a drug; and (5) a technique that enables the robot to be imaged at the same time it is being powered by the MR scanner. The outcomes of this project provide a foundation for other researchers and clinicians who wish to develop techniques for performing interventions guided in real time by the excellent soft tissue imaging provided by MRI.
